cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ecosystems possess the property of stability.
remarks: Captures that stability is conceptually tied to ecosystems as a characteristic.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ecosystems are characterized as having an overall health state (ecosystem condition).
remarks: May overlap with intrinsic property modeling of ecosystem condition.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Health of ecosystems is an attribute describing the condition of ecosystems.
remarks: Modeled as ecosystems having the attribute ‘health of ecosystems’.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Resilience of ecosystems is an attribute of ecosystems describing their capacity to withstand disturbances.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Relates an entity to an attribute, state, or condition that characterizes it (e.g., ecosystems having stability, condition, health, or resilience).
args.justification: In all four relations, the subject 'ecosystems' is linked to a characterizing quality (stability, condition, health, resilience). Despite minor wording differences in relation_name and rel_hint_type, they all express the same predicate-level meaning of an entity possessing an attribute or state, so they should share a unified canonical predicate 'has_attribute'.

All four relations connect ecosystems to descriptors of their state or condition (stability, overall condition, health, resilience). This fits a common relation class capturing attributes that represent the state of an ecosystem, more specific than a generic attribute_relation.
The broad semantic dimension for linking an entity to its properties, states, or qualities is an attribute-type relation, so all four should be grouped under ATTRIBUTE.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Relates an entity to an attribute, state, or condition that characterizes it (e.g., ecosystems having stability, condition, health, or resilience).

Despite minor wording differences in relation_name and rel_hint_type, they all express the same predicate-level meaning of an entity possessing an attribute or state, so they should share a unified canonical predicate 'has_attribute'.

All four relations connect ecosystems to descriptors of their state or condition (stability, overall condition, health, resilience). This fits a common relation class capturing attributes that represent the state of an ecosystem, more specific than a generic attribute_relation.
The broad semantic dimension for linking an entity to its properties, states, or qualities is an attribute-type relation, so all four should be grouped under ATTRIBUTE.
